title.value: Global Variations in Event-Based Surveillance for Disease Outbreak Detection: Time Series Analysis
title.justification: The title explicitly describes the subject and methodology of the study.
title.quote: Global Variations in Event-Based Surveillance for Disease Outbreak Detection: Time Series Analysis

extractions.description: This study evaluates the global performance of two event-based surveillance systems, HealthMap and EIOS, in detecting seasonal influenza outbreaks across 24 countries. The paper investigates how these systems perform in terms of timeliness and accuracy compared to traditional surveillance models, analyzing factors influencing the variability in performance across different geographic and socioeconomic settings.

type.justification: The study involves systematic monitoring and data analysis from real-world surveillance systems.
type.quote: The aim of this study was to assess the variation in the timing and frequency of EBS reports compared to true outbreaks.

name.justification: The research focuses on the efficacy of surveillance systems in detecting disease outbreaks, a key area in public health.
name.quote: The aim of this study was to assess the variation in the timing and frequency of EBS reports compared to true outbreaks and to identify the determinants of variability by using the example of seasonal influenza epidemic in 24 countries.

name.justification: The study specifically examines surveillance systems' performance in detecting infectious disease outbreaks.
name.quote: Event-based surveillance (EBS) was developed to complement IBS to enable near real-time detection of infectious disease outbreaks.

name.justification: FluNet is referenced as the gold standard dataset for evaluating EBS systems in the study.
name.quote: FluNet is a web-based tool created by the World Health Organization (WHO) for disseminating virologic influenza surveillance data and serves as the reference to evaluate EBS systems.

referenced_paper_title.value: World Health Organization report on global surveillance of epidemic-prone infectious diseases
referenced_paper_title.justification: FluNet is developed by WHO for influenza data dissemination and was cited as the reference standard in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: FluNet is a web-based tool created by the World Health Organization (WHO) for disseminating virologic influenza surveillance data.

name.justification: The paper mentions using the "R" software for statistical analysis.
name.quote: All regression models were fit using the R software version 3.6.3.

referenced_paper_title.value: R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing
referenced_paper_title.justification: The official reference for R as noted in the paper is the R foundation for Statistical Computing.
referenced_paper_title.quote: R Core team. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria: R Foundation for Statistical Computing; 2019.

name.justification: The change point analysis was conducted using the R package bcp.
name.quote: All BCP analyses were conducted using the R package bcp, version 4.0.3.

referenced_paper_title.value: A fast Bayesian change point analysis for the segmentation of microarray data
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper bcp is noted for the method implemented in the analyses.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A fast Bayesian change point analysis for the segmentation of microarray data.
